docs.lead_paragraph: New Jersey's treasury has been fattened by so much unexpected money this year that it may surprise many taxpayers that state officials are considering an increase in the gasoline tax. Like other states basking in the nation's continuing economic boom, New Jersey reported a record budget surplus this fiscal year -- $782 million -- as steady increases in business profits and personal income swelled incoming revenues. The national settlement with tobacco companies will bestow an additional $7 billion windfall on the state, to be paid over 25 years.

headline.main: New Jersey Weighs Tax Increase On Gasoline Despite Big Surplus

docs.abstract: New Jersey officials weigh increasing gasoline tax, despite state's fat treasury and $782-million budget surplus; 10.5-cent-per-gallon tax increase is being considered to pay for several costly plans, including $10-billion school construction program; Gov Christine Whitman has pledged to use most of tobacco settlement windfall for health insurance, and has proposed $100-million plan to provide insurance to low- and moderate-income families; property-tax rebate program will return $200 million to taxpayers, and state must also replenish transportation trust fund; New Jersey's current gas tax is one of lowest in US, and voters have reacted angrily to other recent tax increases (M)
docs.snippet: New Jersey's treasury has been fattened by so much unexpected money this year that it may surprise many taxpayers that state officials are considering an increase in the gasoline tax.     Like other states basking in the nation's continuing economic...
docs.section_name: Health; Education; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: You ask (editorial, Dec. 27), ''In a $9 trillion economy that is experiencing the best economic times ever, is it worth spending $100 billion a year on universal coverage, something other, less wealthy industrialized countries have already achieved?'' This encapsulates the issue well. But limiting the answer to a choice between Al Gore's or Bill Bradley's proposals is too shortsighted.

headline.main: Bradley vs. Gore, on Health Care

docs.abstract: David Weiner letter on Dec 27 editorial on Bill Bradley's and Vice Pres Gore's proposals on health care coverage
